text: Our camera is MOUNTED to a CAR WINDOW. Driving through a small town at night. Passing white picket fences. Kids' discarded big wheels. American flags flutter. July 4th, 1969 - Summer of Love. Vallejo, California FIREWORKS streak into the sky. Cookouts winding down. The car slows. Stops in front of a house on Beechwood Avenue. The driver HONKS. MIKE MAGEAU races out. Skinny at 19. Runs up to the window. To the camera:
Where have you been? I've been waiting since seven. At the wheel is DARLENE FERRIN, 22, clad in a WHITE AND B JUMPSUIT. Fake eyelashes and braces make her look like 17
(good natured) Get in, I'm starving. I haven't eaten in like twenty four hours.
Let me drive, then.
No way, Jose. I have to pick up fireworks for the party tonight. Food first though. Mike doesn't move - he wants to drive.
You coming or not?

BOOM DOWN to see a local Vallejo teen hangout. Although t 60's are almost over, Vallejo didn't get the memo. Darlen (still driving) and Mike, cruising through the crowded lo She sees something offscreen. Frowning, unnerved:
Screw this place.
I thought you needed to eat. (CONTINUED)
We have time before the party. We could just go talk. Mike blinks at this. An opportunity...
Minutes later. The Corvair pulls into the lot of the loca golf course. Make out point. The car on the road behind them, passing, continuing on.
Darlene, parking, checking the rearview to watch the car pass. Tense, but relaxing as it goes. Mike, noticing.
Are you okay?
(relaxing) Fine.
You seem a little funny. She touches his chest, playfully.
It's July and how many shirts are you wearing?
(embarrassed) I'm cold.

You're cold in July? BANG-BANG-BANG! Mike and Darlene JUMP and Mike gives out scream! Looking around to see KIDS. A group of them in three cars. Laughing, they toss another lit string of fireworks towards the Corvair. BANG-BANG-BANG!
Fuck off and die! The kids PEEL OUT. Leaving Mike and Darlene alone. After moment, Darlene begins giggling. RELAXING.
What? (CONTINUED)
(mimicking) "Fuck off and die!" She keeps laughing.

Shut up... But he's smiling. Soon he succumbs to the laughter as wel He shifts closer. Then, through the windshield - HEADLIGH Signaling to turn into the lot. The car pulls to a halt eight feet behind them on their left side. Turning out th lights. But not the engine. Mike stares at the car. Only one person in it. Odd for a make out spot.
Is that the car that was behind us before? Darlene doesn't respond.
(squinting) It is, I think he's been with us since my house- Shit, is that your husband?
No. But she can't take her eyes off the car. The driver makes move to get out...

I can to tell him to leave- She puts her hand over his. Looks at him. Don't move. The wait for what seems an eternity. Then... The other car PULLS FORWARD. Headlights click BACK ON. Passing the Corvair. They watch it go, finally disappeari over the horizon.
Who was that, Darlene?
Don't worry about it. Mike studies her face. Unnerved.
So... do you want to- (CONTINUED)
Oh, shit... Through the windshield - HEADLIGHTS, COMING BACK over the horizon. Darlene and Mike watch them reach the entrance t the parking lot. THEY TURN IN.
Let's go. Darlene, FROZEN.

Now, Darlene. The car pulls to a halt behind the Corvair. In an off-lin position, like a COP. Mike, reaching over to start the engine when - A SPOTLIGH from inside the other car hits the Corvair. The door opens and THE COP inside gets out. Walks up to t car. Flashlight outstretched, shining it in Mike and Darlene's faces, blinding them. He reaches Mike's door.

Get your I.D. (rolls down his window) Man, you kinda creeped us-— THUNK! Mike's BLOOD AND TEETH EXPLODE onto the dashboard. The muzzle of a SILENCER FLASHES. The Man KEEPS SHOOTING. BULLETS PUNCH through flesh and bone. Some shots rip stra through Mike and into Darlene. Mike is shot in the face, the neck, and the arm. Darlene shot twice in each arm, and three times in the back. The Man lowers the gun. Silence. The Man turns away. Walking back to his car. A GROAN. The Man turns. Walks back to the Corvair, reloading. Mike. Still alive. The Man FIRES TWO MORE SHOTS into Mike, propelling him in the BACK SEAT. Then TWO MORE into Darlene for good measur The Man turns and walks away.
P.O.V. the front of a police motorcycle as it's HEADLIGHT cuts into the lot... OVER THIS WE HEAR a coin clink into phone. One number dialed.
Vallejo Police Department? The headlight, SWINGING over asphalt until it comes to re on MIKE, slumped against the REAR of the Corvair. Blood, running down his shirt...
I want to a report a double murder... The Officer (HOFFMAN) dismounts and runs to him...

If you go one mile east on Columbus Parkway to the public park, you will find kids ina brown car... Mike gestures - and Hoffman goes to the front seat to fin Darlene. In even worse shape. She tries to mouth somethin
They were shot with a nine millimeter Luger. I also killed those kids last year. Goodbye. CLICK. The line goes dead. SMASH TO OUR TITLE SCREEN...
August 1, 1969. SOARING OVER WATER towards the Bay City. Magnificent spires and bridges. Bustling to life.

ROBERT GRAYSMITH stands, brushing his teeth. Mid 20's. Ne to him, his 4 year old son DAVID brushes his teeth as wel Mimicking his father's movements. Graysmith does his top teeth, David does his. Graysmith smiles. David smiles. Graysmith scrubs his tongue, David scrubs his.
And spit. (CONTINUED)
Graysmith spits. David does not.
I swallowed it.
Why?
It was minty. Graysmith laughs and scoops David up.
The tiny apartment is cluttered. Dick Tracy and old myste movie posters abound. The TV PLAYS while Graysmith ties David's shoes.
+..at the Hall of Justice vow that the rapist will be arrested and brought to trial... Graysmith frowns and shuts off the TV.
__, (giggling) Rapist! Rapist!
Do daddy a favor and don't yell that at preschool, okay?
Rapist!
Much better. He finishes David's shoes.
Are we gonna see Mom and Aaron tonight? Graysmith winces a little. Glances at the clock.
We're gonna be late.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 7.
Graysmith kisses his son on the forehead and sends him inside. Then turns and RUNS...
Traffic's bad. Graysmith sketching something in his lap a he inches along. We get a good look - FOUR CARTOON SKETCH Very rough, but good...

Graysmith hustles down the sidewalk amongst pedestrians. Behind him, a MAIL TRUCK passes him on the street Both, coming up to the SAN FRANCISCO CHRONICLE, a grand old building on Fifth and Mission. The logo above the entranc Graysmith pushes through the doors into
Graysmith hurries across the lobby towards and OPEN ELEVA The DOORS CLOSE just before he can reach it...
The TRUCK halts by a LOADING DOCK. TWO MEN get out and be unloading large DUFFEL BAGS of mail onto a FLATBED DOLLY.

DING! Graysmith emerges from the elevator into the controlled chaos of the paper's editorial offices. Phones ring. Typewriters clack. Reporters hustle. Graysmith head to a small COFFEE STAND manned by an ill tempered white haired midget named SHORTY.
How's the coffee today, Shorty? Shorty points upward at his sign - "DELICIOUS AS HELL COF AND SANDWICHES".
The Mailmen ride up towards the third floor with a smalle MAIL CART that's marked "Editorial".
15 16 17 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 8.

Graysmith gets his coffee from Shorty and heads to his de getting hung up by a CROWD OF PEOPLE standing around -— PAUL AVERY'S DESK. Avery, 30's, well dressed, crime reporter. Currently entertaining the crowd with a joke.

...and the bartender says, “Superman, you are one mean son of a bitch when you're drunk!" The others laugh. Graysmith pushes through them. Reaching his own desk. Devoid of people, away from the action. He opens his briefcase, just settling in when

Editorial in two! Graysmith begins regathering up his things as - The ELEVATOR doors across the room open and the MAILMEN emerge. We pick them up again, traveling the length of th Third Floor offices and into

Where the cart is DUMPED OUT onto a CAROL FISHER'S desk. stay on the LETTER PILE as the she begins to sort them. We zoom in on follow ONE LETTER in particular. Rush to Editor is chickenscrawled twice on it. Through the door, see GRAYSMITH - last through into the EDITORIAL ROOM.
All right let's get going. Graysmith shuts the door. Carol begins opening the letter
TEMPLETON PECK, privileged and ascoted runs the Editorial Meeting around a long oak table. As he goes through Graysmith's sketches one by one:
Horrid, horrid, not horrid, and horrid. I'm thinking we go with not horrid, don't you? (CONTINUED)
18 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 9.
Graysmith just nods meekly and takes the sketches back.
Carol slices open the Rush To Editor letter...
Paul, what's on the crime beat?
Janice in Datebook won't let me take her to dinner. (off Peck's look) What? It's a crime. Graysmith cracks the slightest of smiles. Interrupted as door opens revealing Carol Fisher. Face grave.
Carol, what do you-
You need to see this. She lays the Rush to Editor letter on the table. The othe crowd around. Scanning it. Peck looks up to Carol.
Go get the publisher.
CHARLES DE YOUNG THEIRIOT - sits at the head of the table Old, patrician, reading the letter aloud.

Dear Editor. This is the murderer of the two teenagers last Christmas at Lake Herman and the girl on the 4th of July near the golf course in Vallejo. To prove I killed them, I shall state some facts which only I and the police know. Christmas - Brand name of ammo Super X. Ten shots were fired. The boy was on his back with his feet to the car. The girl.
(CONTINUED)
He hands the letter to Peck with distaste. Motioning for to continue.

The girl was on her right side, feet to the west. July 4th - One girl was wearing patterned slacks. The boy was also shot in the knee. Brand name of ammo was Western. Here is part of a cipher. The other two parts of the cipher are being mailed to the editors of the Vallejo Times and S.F. Examiner. NEXT PAGE - Full of strange symbols. A CODE.

I want you to print this cipher on the front page of your paper. In this cipher is my identity. If you do not print this cipher by the afternoon of Fry. The Ist of August 69, I will go on a kill rampage Fry night. I will cruise around all weekend killing lone people in the night then move on to kill again until I end up with a dozen people over the weekend". (pause) It's unsigned except for a symbol. Peck puts the letter down. The others move forward to examine it. Seeing the SYMBOL:
Is it me, or does that look like a gunsight? Lost among them, Graysmith picks up THE CODE. WEIRD SYMBO litter the page in UNBROKEN BLOCK PARAGRAPHS...
Today is August first. He wants his code in the afternoon edition.
If the Examiner doesn't have the balls to run it, we scoop the Bay-
Charles, this man is talking about shooting twelve people- (CONTINUED)
FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT ll.
And not running this could make him do that-
If we run it we could be setting a very dangerous precedent-
Oh, come on, it's newsworthy-
We'd be giving this sick bastard a soapbox. What does that say to people?
Back up. The Vallejo stuff, is it true?
Paul?
What, I cover crime in Vallejo? (off Theiriot's look) I cover crime in Vallejo. He rises and exits to make calls. Hyman, to Theiriot:
Let's shoot the code and call SFPD. If it turns out to be real, at least we'll have the material. A beat. Theiriot nods.
Copy! A COPY BOY sticks his head in.
Get Grant in here, we need some photos. Graysmith? Graysmith looks up from the code, his reverie broken.
Don't you have a cartoon to finish? Graysmith takes the hint. Puts down the code and leaves.  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 12.
Graysmith, wandering back to his desk. Passing Avery who sits, dialing. Graysmith, hoping to hear the conversation
(into the phone) This is Paul Avery from the San Francisco Chronicle, I'm looking for someone to shed some light on a letter we received...
SERGEANT JACK MULANAX (40's hook-nosed), on the phone.
You want to run it, run it-
Jack, you got a guy from the Chronicle on two!
Lenny, hang on... (clicks over) Sergeant Mulanax.
Sergeant, this is Paul Avery at the Chronicle. I just wanted to check if you had an unsolved firearm related homicide on Christmas and maybe one on July 4th?
(through phone) Shit, you got one too?
Avery re-enters to find Hyman on the phone.
Al's on with the Examiner, they got the same letter, but with a different code. (CONTINUED)
22 23 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 13.

(checking his notes) So did the Times Herald. VPD confirmed the shootings; Christmas, two teenagers on lover's lane, both DOA, David Farraday and Betty Jensen - July 4th, Darlene Ferrin and Michael (trying to pronounce) Mah- Mag- I think it's "Mayhew" He lived. She didn't.
The murder weapons?
Match the calibers he gives in the letter. I bet the Times Herald will go with it. Hyman cups his hand over the receiver to update them:
Examiner says they're going but won't go front page. I say we go front page and if he kills twelve people, it's not our fault. Theiriot heaves a long sigh as the debate continues...

Graysmith, at his desk. Unfinished cartoon pushed aside. doodles something else - THE CODE. Recreated from memory. He looks up to see the ENTIRE EDITORIAL STAFF of the pape now in with Theiriot. Carol Fisher stops by his desk.
Robert, we need- You're not done yet?
Sorry. He switches to the cartoon.
Theiriot's still here.
He's never here this late... Graysmith scoops up his finished cartoon and heads for  24 25 26 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 14.
Hyman speaks as Graysmith slips in.
...ten minutes to press, Charles. Theiriot, quiet. Thinking. Graysmith hovers with his cartoon near Peck who whispers:
Leave it.
(deciding) Okay, replate, we'll go page 4. Weary, but happy a decision has been made, the staff head for the exit. Avery, commenting to the others:
Twenty bucks to the first person who cracks the guy's name.
(quietly) He won't give his name. Avery turns, surprised the quiet cartoonist has spoken. Graysmith looks a little surprised too.
(to everybody) Anyone wanna grab a drink?
Graysmith heads home. Passing "MORTI'S", a BAR near the CHRONICLE. Looking through the window - Avery and several others from the paper laughing, carousing. He watches for moment, then moves on.
THE CODE - Sitting on a white table, CAMERA mounted above CHOOM! CHOOM! Flashbulbs go off. Being shot for print.  27 28 29 30 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15.

Graysmith dumps a stack of LIBRARY BOOKS on his desk. Dav grabs the top one happily - Yertle the Turtle. All the others, about CODEBREAKING or MURDER. Graysmith looks at the wall - covered with reproductions of JAMES BOND NOVEL COVERS. He sighs. Begins taking some down. We can't see his hands. He moves away and we see he's tacked THE CIPHE up in their place. As we push in on SYMBOLS...
All right, people, listen up...
A group of CRYPTOGRAPHERS seated around a table with the cipher. The PROJECT LEADER addresses them.
The cipher is broken into three sections - each one is eight lines with seventeen symbols...
A similar gathering of codebreakers.
No breaks between the symbols denoting different words, no numbers or clues to substitution keys...
Two codebreakers sit at their desks, splitting a sandwich
And you got symbols from at least seven different sources - Greek, Morse Code, Navy Semaphore, Weather Symbols, Astrological Signs...  31 32 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 16.
DONALD and BETTYE HARDEN sit perusing their morning paper Donald examines the PRINTED CODE. He studies it. A beat.
Hey, take a gander at this code thingy. He passes it to his wife. She looks intrigued.
Want to give it a go?
August 7, 1969. Graysmith, working on the day's cartoon.
The guy who used to sit there was a great cartoonist. Graysmith looks up to see Avery.
Bob Bastion. Now he's on public television for some reason... Paul Avery.
Robert Graysmith. I've been here nine months.
You were right, by the way. He didn't give his name. That gets Graysmith's attention.
Who cracked it?

A history teacher and his wife in Salinas. He lays the translation of the code down on the desk. Graysmith picks it up. Begins reading aloud, the horror growing on his face with every sentence. (CONTINUED)
32 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 17.

I like killing people because it is so much fun. It is more fun than killing wild game in the forest because man is the most dangerous animal of all to kill. Something gives me the most thrilling experience, it is even better than getting your rocks off with a girl. The best part of it is that when I die I will be reborn in paradise and they - They I have killed will become my slaves. I will not give you my name because you will try to slow down or stop my collecting of slaves for the afterlife. Silence. Graysmith, shaken.
Methinks our friend is a tad bit fuckered in the head. I heard he even sent Vallejo a code key to help. Impatient prick, isn't he?
What are those letters at the bottom? He points and we see them - EBEORIETMETHHPITI
Leftovers? Maybe an anagram? Graysmith begins writing, trying different permutations o the letters: Robert Hemphill, Van M. Blackman, Robert Emm the Hippie...
You're pretty good at those. (noticing) "Robert Emmet the Hippie"? Graysmith tries more. Avery watches. After a bit:
How'd you know he wasn't gonna give his name? (CONTINUED)
32 33 34 35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 18.

(to himself) Man is the most dangerous animal of all... Man is the most dangerous animal of all... He continues writing and mumbling. This guy is strange. Avery walks away, intrigued. Passing Peck, who whispers:
Paul, editorial now.
The EDITORIAL STAFF huddled, going through something. Ave pushes through them. Bumping into Hyman.
Another letter, more of the same -— details about the murders. He taped a flashlight to the gun, that's how he hit them in the dark-
But he gave himself a name. Avery looks down as we push in on the NEW LETTER:

VROOM! A VOLKSWAGEN KARMANN GHIA ROARS past camera, speed down a winding road carved out of the forest above LAKE BERRYESSA. Two college kids, BRYAN HARTNELL at the wheel, CECELIA SHEPHARD next to him. Young. Pretty. Smitten. September 27, 1969 - Napa County, California
The sun, creeping down. The light's gone golden. Bryan an Cecelia lie side by side, on a peninsula. Two trees shade them. No one else in sight. (CONTINUED)
35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 19.
This used to be a town. The county decided the land would work better as a lake, so they flooded it. There's an entire-
-hidden city under the water. We were here last spring, remember? He smiles. She smiles back but then SEES SOMETHING.
Somebody else is here. Bryan stays in his position. Not looking.
It's a public park.
He's watching us.
Well, we're very good looking. Cecelia playfully swats him. Looking back to the brush.
Where'd he go? She scans the landscape.
There. He went behind a tree.
(still not looking) So? He's taking a leak. A beat.

Oh, my God, he's got a gun! Bryan turning to see - The TREE only TWENTY FEET AWAY. A MAN IN BLACK has emerged from behind it. Wearing A HOOD l an EXECUTIONER'S MASK. Slits for eyeholes and over them, sunglasses. The hood's front with a CROSS STITCHED into i which QUARTERS A CIRCLE. A SHEATHED KNIFE hangs from his left side and a GUN IN HAND. Bryan and Cecelia, beginning stand... The Man walks over, aiming the weapon at them. (CONTINUED)
Don't move, I want your money and your car keys. Don't move.

Whatever you say. We'll cooperate, okay? What do you want us to do? The Man motions for them to stand. They do. Bryan is "water side" standing parallel to the man. Cecelia is to Bryan's right. The Man keeps his distance. Bryan pulls ou the his wallet and tosses it. Searching his pockets for t keys, motor-mouthing:
You're welcome to everything I have, but is there something more I could do? Could I give you a check or something?
No.
I could give you my phone number, and, you know- maybe I could give you more help than you think you need-
(explaining) He's a sociology major.
Sorry, I can't remember where I put the keys, they might be on the blanket, can I- The Man motions with the gun - Bryan leans down to search their blanket.
Can I ask you a question? I read in Reader's Digest that thieves don't always have their guns loaded-
It's loaded.
Bryan, do what he says. (CONTINUED)
35 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21.
I am, I am. (finding them) Here's the keys. Bryan tosses them.
I want her to tie you up.

Okay. He pulls some lengths of hollow core clothesline from beh his back. Hands them to Cecelia who immediately goes behi Bryan and begins tying his hands behind his back, loosely Bryan, to Cecelia as she works:
(whispering) I might be able to get the gun-
Bryan! The Man points the gun at his head.
Don't get any ideas-
I won't-
I killed a guard escaping from prison in Montana.
I'm not doing anything, okay?
I'm not afraid to kill again.

(after a bit; as she ties) What was the name of that prison? The Man doesn't respond. They stand in silence as Cecelia finishes. The Man immediately goes to her and begins bind her hands behind her back (he may have holstered the gun do this). (CONTINUED)
You said it was in Montana, right?
I'm taking your car and going to Mexico. The Man finishes with Cecelia and steps behind Bryan.
She tied you loose, didn't she? He CRANKS the ropes around Bryan's wrists tighter.
Get on your stomach so I can tie your feet.
Come on, man. I didn't complain when you tied our hands-
On your stomach-
It gets cold at night, we could freeze- The Man steps points the gun at him at point blank range:
Get down! Right now! Bryan and Cecelia do. The Man binds Bryan's feet to his hands in silence. Does the same to Cecelia. Hog-tying the Then steps back, surveying his handiwork.

Now that it's all said and done - was the gun really loaded? The Man pops the clip. Removes a SHINY BULLET. Showing Bryan. Then puts it away. Moving behind him, out of his line of vision. Bryan, lying there, trying to figure out he's going to get himself untied once the Man leaves when The Man pulls the KNIFE from the scabbard and STABS BRYAN THE BACK. It happens so quick, it takes a moment for Cece to realize what's happening. And then she begins to SCREA The Man pulls the knife out of Bryan. RAISES IT AGAIN... And Dear God, we're actually going to have to watch this. (CONTINUED)
35 36 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 23.

Blood flowing. On Cecelia. Screaming. Crimson flecks on her face. Bryan's face, in a daze. Jarred forcibly every time the Man stabs down. He does it six times, then lurch off him. He turns and STABS CECELIA. She tries to roll. H just keeps stabbing. Her side. Her front. Bryan's eyes. Finding Cecelia. Seeing what's happening to her. And then looking away...

Later. The screaming is done. The sun, almost down. Cecelia has rolled to her side. Her bound wrists now up b Bryan's mouth and he's trying to CHEW THEM FREE. He spits out some rope. Pulling at the knot with his teeth between sobs... Her hand comes free. She moves... and SCREAMS. We can't hear it, because OVER THIS WE HEAR - More coins in pay phone. Dialing. Ringing...
Napa Police Department? Bryan rolls. Positioning his wrists by Cecelia's free han
I want to report a murder - no, a double murder. With an incredible effort she begins tugging on his ropes
They are two miles north of Park Headquarters. They were in a white Volkswagen Kharmann Ghia. Bryan's wrists come free...
I'm the one that did it. CLICK. He's hung up. Bryan, pulling the ropes from his legs. He crawls to Cecelia. Kisses her once on the lips.

I'll get someone... Somehow, he manages to STAND. Stooped over, arms crossed around his stomach. Just one step is an amazing effort. Bryan takes three before COLLAPSING. He only made it six feet. He rises again. Walks again. Falls again. Finally he gives up... And begins to crawl.  37 38 39 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 24.

..-above the Lake. Bryan's car, still pulled off to the s of the empty road. A PARK RANGER slows at the abandoned c Nothing out of the ordinary. He rolls his eyes. Kids. He drives on. We stay on the car. Slowly moving to the passenger side to reveal SCRAWLED IN MARKER ON THE DOOR: °
CLOSE ON - Graysmith's fingers grip a pencil. SKETCHING.

The boy lived, the girl didn't. Imagine surviving something like that. And the dates on the car - the two Vallejo killings and now the one in Napa. Why Napa? Pulling back to reveal it's a sketch of ZODIAC IN COSTUME
What's he doing out of Vallejo? And- Sweet Christmas, what are you drawing? By now we can tell we're by Graysmith's desk.
The kid who survived, this is what he said Zodiac was wearing- He stops, his EYES GOING WIDE as something clicks.
Oh, my God... He leaps up and races off. Practically knocking over Hyma An odd duck, that one. Hyman sits and picks up the sketch
Jesus, where'd he come up with that? (CONTINUED)
It's Zodiac at the lake. (re: Graysmith) What's his story, anyway? He seems a little farther out than far out.
Graysmith? He's a fucking boy scout. Doesn't smoke, doesn't drink, doesn't curse.

Horrible. (seeing) Aaand he's back. As Graysmith returns to the desk clutching a FILM BOOK. H puts it down, frantically paging through it. He turns the book to Avery and Hyman and stabs the page: A black and white FILM STILL from an old movie - a man DRESSED IDENTICALLY AS THE ZODIAC.
What is that?
A still from The Most Dangerous Game.
"The Most Dangerous Game"?
It's a movie about a count who hunts people for sport. "Man is the most dangerous animal of all" I knew I'd heard it somewhere!
And this is the Count?
Exactly. "Count Zaroff".
"Zaroff" with a 2?
Jesus. He's hunting people...
October 11, 1969. We SOAR OVER the CITY, passing through half completed TRANSAMERICA PYRAMID. A RADIO SHOW: (CONTINUED)

...news on the Twenty. Because of the recent attacks police have ordered curfews in effect tonight for the following counties - Napa, Solano, Contra Costa, Alameda, Marin, and San Mateo so please everyone, stay safe, stay inside, and keep calling. Pushing down into the bustling streets of the city - peop way too busy with their urban lives to be bothered with anything else.
Vic in San Francisco, you're on the line. So the Zodiac doesn't scare you?

Heck no, the guy's just doing his thing out in the sticks. What's really scary is the yippies down in the Haight with their "free love". 4l EXT. MASON AND GEARY -- NIGHT 4l Heavy foot traffic. The THEATER CROWD just being let out. couple hippies play guitar for change.
Alfred from Vacaville feels differently - Alfred, are you gonna take that?

Well, I agree about the hippies, but I resent him calling us "the sticks" - those were nice clean cut young people that man killed. We have good solid Christian communities here in the North Bay.  42 43 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27.
We track the Cab's progress, moving from the business and theater district towards the residential PACIFIC HEIGHTS.
You bring up a good question - is the Zodiac a Satanist? Amber from Oakland, what do you think?
Well, the symbols look Satanic, but that's not what I called about - my question is where does the Chronicle get off encouraging him like that?

A great question, and I'd also ask - since when did a big city paper like the Chronicle even care about what happens in rural communities like Vallejo? Aren't they covering this just to sell more papers? Alison in San Francisco?
I don't know about them caring or not caring but I do know The Zodiac demanded they print his letters or he'd kill more people-
(breaking in) But they didn't have to. And he's killed more people anyway.
The cab slowing. A posh part of the city. The sidewalks, empty. Pulling to halt at the corner of Washington and Cherry. The Cabbie puts it in park...

A great point Amber. So a general question for all our callers, what do you think he'll do next? BOOM! The Cabbie's HEAD SNAPS FORWARD. Shot by his PASSENGER, who we don't see. Silence. As we begin to pull away from the CAB... (CONTINUED)
43 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 27A.

The PASSENGER gets out. Moving around the car. Gets into the FRONT PASSENGER seat. Leaves the door ajar. He seems be (but is not) cradling the Cabbie's head in his lap. We still pulling up and away slowly, across the street... OVER THIS: A phone ringing. Picked up.
San Francisco Police-
Yeah, there's a fight! In a cab! (CONTINUED)
What is your location?
The corner of Washington and Cherry, one's drunk! We think he's robbing him! The Man gets out again. Walks around the front to the Driver's side door. Holding a RAG. Still PULLING BACK...
Is the crime still in progress?
Yes! And then, the sound of a MACHINE GUN...

Good evening. Our top story tonight, the San Francisco Police Department has confirmed that the man who called himself Zodiac and terrorized the Bay Area has broken his silence of fifty one months. In a letter claiming "I am back with you" the Zodiac makes no overt threats against the citizenry, and muses that his life and times would make the basis for a good movie. The terse sixty-six word missive also manages to mention both San Francisco Chronicle Columnist Herb Caen and the Department's own Inspector David Toschi by name. Are they targets? Or is something more at work here? Our team coverage on the Cipher Slayer's Return begins as Alan Freeman has more... DURING THIS - Graysmith looks up reflexively. Then sees Melanie staring at him. He tries to be good. The kids, watching this tennis match of looks. Takes a bite.
These carrots are delicious-
Oh, just go. Graysmith bolts out of his chair and rushes into the livi room. The kids follow. ON TV:

...-Thank you, Eric. These personal mentions have drawn controversial accusations from at least one source tonight as San Francisco Chronicle columnist Armistead Maupin has charged that not only is the new letter be a forgery, but that it was written by Toschi himself - the very man charged to hunt the Killer. Graysmith face pales. (CONTINUED)

text: Maupin, a respected author best known for his "Tales of the City" stories, has gone on the record saying he believes Toschi wrote the letter to drum up publicity for himself. And the theory is gaining strength. Sources wishing to remain anonymous within the Hall of Justice say that Toschi has always had a weak spot where publicity was concerned...
TOSCHI'S WIFE, on the phone with Graysmith. Speaking in hushed tones so her husband doesn't overhear. INTERCUT:

Maupin used David as a character in his column. David got a kick out of it so he wrote a couple anonymous letters asking for the character to be brought back. It was like writing fan mail to himself, that's all. But David didn't write that letter.
I know he didn't. I'm sure this will all blow over- (CONTINUED)
207 208 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 157.
Blow over? She looks into the next room where Toschi sits. Staring o the window. DEVASTATED.
They kicked him out of Homicide. They made him give his handwriting like some criminal-
May I talk to him?
No.
Then could you ask if he ever investigated a man named Rick Marshall?
That is all you can think about?

Mr. Graysmith, Maupin works at your paper. We trusted you- Cut off as TOSCHI takes the phone from her and HANGS IT U Exchanges a look with his wife. Then he turns and goes ba to the living room, to sit with his drink.
Graysmith with Narlow.
Of course he doesn't want to talk, his career's over and your paper did it. I got half a mind to kick you out of here myself-
Does the name Rick Marshall mean anything to you? This stops Narlow cold. He goes and shuts his office door Turns back to Graysmith, intrigued:
What are you after? (CONTINUED)
What have you got?

Hypothetically? You just named my favorite suspect in the whole case. Couple years ago, I was trying to get his prints? Handed him a photo to look at. He takes it, is about to hand it back when he stops and says "My goodness, I got fingerprints all over this." Then he wipes them off.
Why wasn't he ever tested for handwriting?
Because they finally did get his prints and cleared him against the one in Stine's cab.
(deflating) So it's not him.
Maybe yes, maybe no.
What do you mean?
Zodiac left gloves behind. If you have the foresight to wear gloves while committing a murder, how the hell do you leave a fingerprint?
But it was in blood. They found it at the scene-
All it takes is one curious civilian or cop to reach out and touch something and boom - false print. Take a look at the crime scene photos, the cab wasn't that secure.
That print was used to disqualify thousands of suspects. (CONTINUED)
Which is why we also used handwriting.
But not with Marshall.
SFPD had a handwritten sign from the window of his house. Looked nothing like the Z letters so they moved on.
What if he didn't write the sign?
My thoughts exactly. Marshall was a Navy man, received code training. He used to work as a projectionist at a silent film theater- Graysmith looks up.
How much do you want to bet one of the films he projected was "The Most Dangerous Game"? Silence. Narlow stares at him.
How can I get a copy of Rick Marshall's handwriting?
Only three ways. One, get a warrant, which you can't - Two, get him to volunteer it which he won't-
And three?
Get creative.
Graysmith, on the phone with Morrill. (CONTINUED)
I don't know what to tell you. You get it, I'll analyze it. Beyond that, you're on your own. Graysmith runs his fingers through his hair.
What about the man who came to see you? The one who called me-
Wallace Penny.
Did he leave a number?
209A Graysmith, dialing. The phone ringing. Then: 209A
Hello?
Hi, this is Robert Graysmith.
How'd you find me?
I need a sample of Rick Marshall's handwriting.
I told you, Vaughn is the key-
Mr. Penny, if Rick Marshall's the Zodiac, I need his handwriting to confirm it. Can you help or not? Silence. Then:
Rick used to draw movie posters for the theater Vaughn worked at. I'll send one down.
211 212 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 161.
Morrill stands over a table. Magnifying glass in hand, an heaping glass of scotch by his side. Examining the movie poster. Behind him, Graysmith waits, holding his breath.
I'll need more samples.
But is it-
About as close as I've ever seen. And that's why I need more. We have to tread lightly here. We are talking about implicating this man as the Zodiac.
I'll get more. I'1l find Vaughn. I'll track down Linda. It's weird, I've tried the DMV, Darlene's family - no one seems to know where she is-
Mr. Graysmith? Most of the writing matches the exemplar. In a way, though, it's the part that doesn't match that scares me the most.
How do you mean?
The only letter on this poster that absolutely, positively does not match, is the letter "k".
Graysmith, brushing his teeth. Melanie, asleep. The PHONE RINGS. Graysmith runs to pick it up.

Hello? (no response) Hello? Who is this- He stops. Listening. Someone is on the other end. Just BREATHING... CLICK. The line goes dead. Graysmith hangs up. Turns to see MELANIE awake. Staring at him. Scared.  213 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 162.
Toschi, leaving for the day. He exits the front of the building with a couple of other cops, laughing and joking Heading down the sidewalk when he hears:
Inspector! Dave! He turns to see Graysmith coming towards him. Looking a little more manic than usual. The other cops, sensing thi guy's a little off. Toschi turns to them:
I'll catch up with you. They go. Toschi turns to Graysmith.
You stop calling my house. That is unacceptable, do you understand?
(taken aback) I need your help to find Linda-
(turning away) Jesus...
We ran some handwriting samples-
We?
I'm working with Sherwood.
Sherwood who got canned from Questioned Documents. Sherwood who drinks like Paul Avery now.
He retired.
Is that what he told you?
Are you saying Sherwood's wrong? (CONTINUED)
I'm saying stop calling my house. He turns to go. Graysmith, desperate to keep the conversation alive, follows him down the street.
We ran them on Rick Marshall-
No, Robert.
I know you don't think it's him-
I mean, no, I'm not having this conversation.
I think Marshall knew Darlene. I can't find Mageau or Linda, but I'm gonna talk to Bob Vaughn- Toschi stops and turns to him. Amazed by the obsession.
You need to get out of this.
What?
Robert, the Rick Marshalls of the world, the blind alleys will suck you dry.
He said he wouldn't announce his murders anymore, he'd just do them!
You know what the chances of arresting someone are now? Too many years gone, too much evidence lost.
But— (CONTINUED)
I've been a cop for twenty five years, murder police for ten. What do you for a living?
You know what I-
You're a cartoonist.
So what are you saying?
Zodiac was my job. It's not yours. Graysmith, hurt. Toschi, satisfied he's gotten the messag He turns to leave when
He's still out there, Dave! Toschi turns back. Looking at him.
If you could just help me find Linda-
I'm done with this. And I am done with you. He turns on his heel and leaves.
Graysmith gets out of his car to see Melanie hurrying dow the steps, harried. Before he can ask:
You were supposed to pick up the boys from soccer.
Oh, God, I'm sorry, it completely slipped my mind-
They're at the Coes. They tried to call you at work. (CONTINUED)
I was with Dave-
So I had to leave my work, come home, I'm going to get them right now.
I'll go-
I'm already here, Robert. I'm going. (getting in the car) You have to stop ignoring them.
I don't ignore them- (off her look) I'm sorry. I'1l spend more time with the kids. I promise.

2 year old Margot sits in a highchair. Graysmith makes he sandwich. DAVID and AARON sit at the table, cross referencing dates from BOOKS, Aaron on the MISSING/MURDER LIST and David has the ASTROLOGICAL CHARTS.
What about September 26, 1970?
I'm checking... What is it?
Lake Tahoe nurse goes missing. David finds the date on the chart.
Uhhh, one day before the Vernal Equinox. Dad?
Mark it. David turns to a LARGE BOARD and marks the nurse's name, of disappearance, and celestial significance.
Got another on June 19, 1971... (CONTINUED)
All right - that's gotta be close to Summer Solstice. David flips through charts to check. He nods. Graysmith delivers Margot her sandwich.
You boys might not want to mention our "special project" to your mother.

How come you guys don't sleep in the same bed now? This stops Graysmith cold. David gives his younger brothe dead arm. Before anyone can speak, the PHONE RINGS. Grateful for the distraction, Graysmith picks up.
Hello?
Mr. Graysmith, it's Ken Narlow. You called?
We've been cross-referencing lunar cycles with the Zodiac's timeline - more often than not each cycle since '69 corresponds with a letter, an attack, or get this - an unsolved homicide.
Who do you have working with you? Graysmith glances at his sons.
Some colleagues.
Dad?
Hang on a moment. (to Aaron) Yeah, buddy?
What's this? (CONTINUED)
And he holds up the UNSOLVED 1969 CODE. at it and we... 166A. Graysmith, staring
215  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 167. 215A ON VIDEO: Graysmith sits awkwardly with an interview August 9, 1979. A NEWSCASTER OVER THIS:

In the decade since the Zodiac's second cipher was received, every federal agency has taken a crack at decoding it. But today, we are pleased to announce that where those agencies had failed, a cartoonist has succeeded. Graysmith, cowed. The interviewer turns to him.
How'd you do it?
Ummm... A lot of books from the library... PULLING BACK from the TV until we realize we're in
PAUL AVERY sits on a stool watching the report. OXYGEN TA perched on the stool next to him. Smoking. A BLUE GIRLY DRINK in front of him. Cackling:
The fucking library...
Graysmith, on the phone. His hand, taking something down. It reads Linda - San Joaquin County Honor Camp.
(into phone) Thank you, so much! He hangs up the phone and turns to see Melanie, ecstatic.
I found Linda! You know why it's taken me so long? Because she's in prison! Isn't that great?
Why'd you do it? (CONTINUED)
He looks at her, confused.
Because she's the key! If she can identify Marshall-
I'm not talking about Linda whoever. You went on TV. You put your face out there for him to see... Graysmith's face falls.
You're being paranoid-
Who's been calling our house? At least once a week and you never let me answer.
It's nobody.
Right. A beat. Staring at her. She stares back.
What's it going to take for you to be done with this, Robert?
I don't have time to talk about this now, I have to meet Bob Vaughn-
Well, that's too bad, because we're talking about it. When's it going to be enough? When you catch him? When you arrest him?
Be serious-
I am. Silence. Graysmith, slowly: (CONTINUED)
217 218 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 169.
I need to know who he is. (pause) I need to stand there and look him in the eye and know it's him.
And that's more important than your family's safety.
I have to do this, Melanie.
Why? (no response) Look at me, Robert. Why?
Because nobody else will. She stares at him.
That's not good enough for me.
I have to go, are you done? She blinks. Stunned. Turns and walks out of the room.
The same address as in the phone book. Graysmith stands o the corner as a car pulls up. Very dark inside. All we se is a LIT CIGARETTE.
Robert Graysmith? Graysmith squints, he can't make out the man's features v well through the rain and darkness.
Mr. Vaughn?
You said you needed to talk to me?
Yes. There's a coffee shop on the corner- (CONTINUED)
218 219 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 170.
Why don't you just come to my house? The light of the cigarette exposes Vaughn's yellow smile.
I wouldn't want to put you out-
It's not far. (tosses the smoke) You can follow me.
Graysmith follows the wild white haired Vaughn through th door of his house and into a cluttered living room.
Thank you for having me over- CLICK. Vaughn LOCKS THE DOOR from the inside WITH A KEY.
Not at all. Vaughn takes a seat in an easy chair. Graysmith clears so magazines off the couch and sits across from him.
I wanted to ask you about a particular film the Avenue may have run when you were an organist there. "The Most Dangerous Game".
Classic. RKO, 1932. Fay Wray. We've run it many times.
How about in 1969?
I'd have to check my records. Why?
You remember the Zodiac Killer? Vaughn's face darkens. (CONTINUED)
This is about Rick Marshall, isn't it? 170A. (CONTINUED)
219  FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 71.
He worked as your projectionist?
For a time. I don't have any occasion to correspond with him these days.
There's a connection between one of the Zodiac attacks and the film-
You mean the symbol. Graysmith doesn't follow. Vaughn pulls out a coil of FILM LEADER.

The Zodiac symbol on film. On the countdown. It's trimmed off each reel before they're shown, but it always arrives with it. First time I saw it in the papers, I immediately thought of this. Graysmith looks - STANDARD ACADEMY LEADER COUNTDOWN, whic looks EXACTLY LIKE A ZODIAC SIGN.
We got a tip that Rick left a film canister with you. Something he told you never to open.
A "tip" about a "mysterious film canister"?
Is it true? Vaughn stares at him. Finally:
Yes.
Have you opened it?
No.
May I see it? (CONTINUED)
219 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 172.
Rick took it back in 1972. Graysmith's face falls.
And this "tip" is how you got it in your head that Rick's the Zodiac?
That and the movie posters.
Excuse me? Graysmith fumbles out the folded poster.
The handwriting on the posters Rick did. It's the closest we've ever come to a match-
Rick didn't draw any posters.
What? No, he did this one-
Mr. Graysmith, I do the posters personally. That's my handwriting. An awful moment. Graysmith looks to the locked door. Vaug stares at him. Hard. Graysmith puts on a brave face. Rises.
I won't take any more of your time-
Not at all. Before you go, I should check on when we played that film.
I don't want to trouble you-
No trouble. The records are just down in the basement. A beat. Graysmith, echoing Toschi: (CONTINUED)
219 220 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 173.
Not many people have basements in California.
(smiling) I do.

The door CREAKS OPEN. Vaughn and Graysmith stand at the t of a rickety wooden staircase. We hear WATER DRIPPING somewhere down in the darkness. Vaughn flicks a switch, a naked bulb snaps on somewhere below. Very little light. Graysmith really doesn't want to be here. Vaughn leads hi down the stairs, hand on his back as they walk.

The very detailed posters I kept, but the one-off cheapos like that one there I just threw into the back alley... Here we go. They finally stop by an overstuffed bookshelf. Vaughn pul one handbound volume from it and begins flipping through pages. Graysmith looks around, nervous. The bulb above them flickers. Vaughn reaches up and tweak it with a finger - the light goes constant again. Above Graysmith's head, the CEILING BOARDS CREAK. As though someone were WALKING AROUND UPSTAIRS.
You live alone? Vaughn nods absently, still searching the book.
Here it is. "The Most Dangerous Game" - ran it May 1969. That would have been about nine weeks before the first Zodiac letter, correct? Graysmith, still looking up at the ceiling.
Yeah...
You believe he saw the film at our theater and was inspired? (CONTINUED)
220 221 222 223 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 174.
More FOOTSTEP CREAKS from above.
You're sure no one else is in the house?
Would you like to go and check?
That's all right. Thanks for everything. Graysmith turns and heads for the stairs. Forcing himself walk, not run. He climbs them, getting into...

Graysmith emerges from the cellar. Looking around. No one He hurries to the door, grasps the knob and... LOCKED. Fr the inside. Graysmith looks for the bolt. No way to unloc it. He's TRAPPED. The floorboards creak behind him and he SPINS TO SEE... VAUGHN. Standing in the cellar doorway. Slowly walking towards him. Menacing. Reaching into his pocket... and pulling out the KEY. He steps past Graysmit and unlocks the door for him.
Have a good night.
Graysmith exits his car, guzzling coffee, hair crazed. Ju back from his meeting with Vaughn, mumbling:
Maybe there are two of them. Marshall did the killing, Vaughn wrote the letters...
Graysmith steps inside and takes two steps before realizi The HOUSE IS SILENT.
Hello? Nothing.
He pokes his head into the room. Beds made. Not slept in.
The same. He stands there. Goes back downstairs.

He sits on the couch. His wife and children. GONE. Holdin a note: "Took the kids to Mom's. Don't call." He looks at the phone. Next to it a note in his own writi One he took down before. "Linda - San Joaquin County Honor Camp." He stares at the two notes. Two paths. But he already kno the one he's taken. He picks up the Linda note...
INT. SAN JOAQUIN HONOR CAMP —- LAUNDRY ROOM - AFTERNOON 2 Graysmith stands as a GUARD walks LINDA DEL BUONO up to h
You got five minutes. INT. SAN JOAQUIN HONOR CAMP —- MEETING ROOM - DAY 225B The Guard departs to a safe distance. Linda taking in Graysmith. He looks terrible. Linda, wary.
What's this about?
Zodiac.
(lighting a smoke) Figures. You got the look.
What look?
Like you got it bad for this. (CONTINUED)
I'm fine.
Right.
Tell me about this "painting party".

Told the cops about it forever ago. Darlene always had lots of boys around, even though she was married. This one guy was weird, though. He used to bring her presents from Mexico. I don't know why she was friends with him. She once told me he'd killed somebody.
Really?
Yup. Maybe when he was in the service.
The Navy?
I think so.
Was he into movies?

He wasn't into people, I can tell you that. This party Darlene threw, people were supposed to show up, have beers, help paint. This dude shows up in a suit. He sat alone in a chair, didn't talk to anyone. Creeped me out. Darlene told me not to go near him. She was scared of him. Couple weeks later, she was dead. She takes a long shaky drag on her cigarette.
Do you remember his name? (CONTINUED)
It was short. Like a nickname. Rob or Stan or-
Rick? Or Bob maybe? She looks at him strangely. A long beat. Then:
No. No, I don't think so.
Rick or Bob - are you sure?
Yeah.
How can you be sure? Think hard-
I am thinking hard- He grasps her arm. The Guard starts moving towards them..
Hey!
Rick Marshall or Bob Vaughn, it was one of those names, wasn't it-
No-
Yes-—
Christ, mister, it wasn't Rick or Bob! The Guard separates them. He stumbles back. Stands there. Wife gone. Life ruined.
I'm sorry. I'll go. He turns and walks away. She watches him go. Broken. Done She blinks as it comes to her:
It was Lee. (CONTINUED)
Graysmith STOPS IN HIS TRACKS.
Leigh? He turns back to her.
Yeah, Leigh. That sounds right...
The rain, now POURING. Graysmith, standing outside of the department. Mulanax blocking his entry. Both men, shoutin at each other over the weather:
I just need to see one file-
I'm sorry, I talked to Dave Toschi. He said I shouldn't-
I remember a name! I saw a name!
Mr. Graysmith, you need to go home-
One file! Please! I've got the name!
(turning away) I'm sorry...
Please! This is all I've got! Mulanax stops. Turning back to him. Graysmith, soaked. At the end of his rope. Begging.
Please... Mulanax steps aside and lets him in.
Graysmith puts a piece of paper down on Mulanax's desk. (CONTINUED)
Here! "Linda states that some of Darlene's closest friends are LEE who used to bring Darlene presents from Tia Juana"-
So what?
He knew her! Linda said Leigh! This is Leigh!
No, that's one name in a file that contains hundreds. It's nothing.
But you said Dave Toschi-
Agrees with me. Our investigation into this suspect is over.

Rain pounds the roof. The contents of his ZODIAC INVESTIGATION now COVER THE EMPTY LIVING ROOM. Tacked up every wall, papers all over the floor. Furniture pushed aside. It's overwhelming. Graysmith, on the floor, scrapi through pages. Hasn't eaten or slept for days. MUMBLING t himself.
You made a mistake somewhere, where were you weak, where did you make a mistake... The phone rings. Graysmith picks up.
Hello? (CONTINUED)
232 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 180.
The BREATHING again. Slow and steady as ever. He SLAMS th phone down. Goes back to a file. Accidentally knocking ov his coffee, dumping it all over the pages.
Goddammit ! Graysmith HEAVES the java soaked file across the room. It lands on the floor next to a pair of FEMALE FEET. Pan up reveal MELANIE, standing in the open doorway.
You didn't return my calls. Graysmith, stunned to see her.
I've been kind of busy.
(looking around) I can see. The book's going well? He doesn't respond. They stare at each other. Two people who no longer know how to act around one another.
I called the Chron...
I'm not a cartoonist anymore.
I heard. When's the last time you ate something?
Can I have that file back? She walks over and hands it to him.
He made a mistake, he made a mistake... It takes him a second to realize he's speaking aloud. Looking up at her. Like a child.
Nothing makes sense anymore... She looks around the room at the mountain of papers. (CONTINUED)
232 233 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 181.
Did it ever?
Yeah. It did. It's clear he's talking about her.
Robert. It was just the date that never ended.
Do you think-
No. He just stares at her, numb. Then nods.
But we have a daughter together. You have two good sons. They miss you.
(looking around) I don't want them to see me like this...

Neither do I. But I will not let you lose them. Do whatever you have to. But finish this. Silence. Melanie turns and walks out. Graysmith sits. Alone. Looking at the MOUNTAINS OF PAPERS. Years of his life, gone. He slowly starts collecting them. Cleaning up Wiping the coffee stained papers off. One, a DMV SHEET on ARTHUR LEIGH ALLEN. And there it is, right at the top. Graysmith stops. STARING at it. And we pull away from him as he stands stock-still rooted to the ground...
The rain has mellowed into a light shower. A TAPPING on t window. Faintly:
(whispering) Dave! Dave! He made a mistake! (CONTINUED)
Toschi blinks awake. Next to him, his wife does the same.
Is he actually here? Toschi sits up. Graysmith seeing him, thrilled:
He made a mistake! I'1l meet you around front!
Robert, don't- But Graysmith's already going from the window, excited. Toschi, pulling on his robe...
Call SFPD, I'm gonna shoot him...
Toschi walking down the hall. Graysmith, now lightly knocking on the door.
Go away, Robert!
You need to hear this-
No I don't!
The birthday! The one time he was weak, the one time he gave something away!
I'm calling the cops-
(screaming) It's Arthur Leigh Allen! A pregnant moment. Graysmith stares at the door. Then - tumblers in the lock. The DOOR SWINGS OPEN revealing (CONTINUED)
Where did you get that name? Graysmith, surprised to be granted an audience. Still

The call to Belli's house December '69, "I have to kill, today's my birthday"? It was his birthday! Arthur Leigh Allen was born on December 18th! He slaps the wet DMV sheet up against the door. DOB 12/18/33. Toschi stares at it. A beat and then...
Get in here.
Toschi hands Graysmith a MUG of steaming coffee, then tak seat across from him at the kitchen table.
He wrote me, you know. (pause) 2500 different suspects. And the only one who ever wrote me a letter is Leigh Allen.
Sometimes killers want to help out-
Robert, I know this. (pause) He was arrested for molestation in January '75. Sent me this when he got out. He slides a LETTER across the table.
“Sorry, I wasn't your man. If I can help out"- This is typewritten.
Using a typewriter isn't a crime.
He knew her, Dave. This was in the Vallejo files. (CONTINUED)
He shows Toschi Linda's statement.
Mulanax said he was your favorite suspect. That you spent two years on him. That nobody else came close-
The evidence all said no. Sherwood disqualified him.
The same Sherwood who drinks like Paul Avery now?
What are you telling me?
Sherwood's wrong. Toschi looks down at the Date of Birth. Then back up to Graysmith.
I'll show you mine, you show me yours.
A misty morning. On a tiny coffee shack below the bridge.
Graysmith and Toschi, in a booth. Empty breakfast plates pushed aside, SURROUNDED by both the SFPD and GRAYSMITH'S ZODIAC FILES. At this all night. Graysmith, gesturing to SFPD handwriting reports.
+..-you have Sherwood in writing saying "I'm sorry this just won't work", and Terry Pascoe-
His protege-
Fine, his protege, but a handwriting expert saying "Do not disqualify this suspect on the basis of handwriting". These two cancel each other out- (CONTINUED)

No, because it was Sherwood's case. He was the head of Questioned Documents. If it went to trial, all the defense would have to do is call Sherwood to the stand - and there was no way to get Allen into court in the first place because there was no evidence.
But you have him seen with ciphers, the military bootprints, the same size shoes and gloves, "The Most Dangerous Game", the Zodiac watch-
Robert-
-the background with school kids, the misspellings of "Christmas", the bloody knives in the car, the connections to the murder scenes-

It's all circumstantial. Stine's shirt, his wallet, his keys - we should have found one of those things in that trailer. We didn't. He sighs, running his hand through his hair. Graysmith an he begins digging through the folders.
Hang on a second.
What?
The trailer, I saw- (finding it) Here. From Catherine Allen - "Leigh cleaned out his trailer Friday after work and took it to Santa Rosa Saturday August 7,
Yeah? (CONTINUED)
Toschi stares
You interviewed him at the refinery Wednesday August 4th. (pause) He's cleaning out his trailer and moving it to a different county 48 hours after you interviewed him. at him.
You have to look at this stuff side by side.
What do you mean?
Allen and the Zodiac. Their timelines. When was the first murder in Vallejo?
Christmas of 68.
Eight months after Allen's fired for molesting children and his family discovers he was a pedophile. When did the letters begin?
July of 69.
After the second murder and they continue until you interview Allen. Did any letters after that contain swatches of Stine's shirt?
No.
Because he dumped it. He got scared. Because you went to see him at work. When's the next time Zodiac wrote?
Not until January of 1974. (CONTINUED)

Which means he's silent for three years after you talk to him. But by '74 he feels safe again. Everyone's moved off Allen as a suspect. So Zodiac writes three new letters - January, May, and July in '74.
But then the letters stopped again.
What happened to Allen?
He was arrested. January of '75. They sent him to Atascadero. We didn't get a single letter while he was in there.
